options.label: C

title: The history of the Cuban Missile Crisis - Matthew A. Jordan

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: How Americans got stuck with endless drug commercials

multiple-choice.question: In most countries, TV commercials for prescription drugs are illegal. However, in the US, they are:

options.label: A
options.text: Only allowed for certain prescription drugs.

multiple-choice.question: Before the 1980s, prescription drug commercials were:

options.label: A
options.text: The FDA's regulations required ads to include all of the information about the drug's risks and side effects.

options.label: B
options.text: The industry couldn't afford to produce TV commercials.

options.label: C
options.text: The ads didn't have to mention the disease or condition that the drug was supposed to treat.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the FDA's 1997 guidance on prescription drug commercials?

options.label: C
options.text: Ads were only allowed for certain prescription drugs.

options.label: D
options.text: Ads were only allowed for over-the-counter medications.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential concern about the impact of prescription drug commercials on public health?

options.label: A
options.text: They may not be reaching the right people.

options.label: B
options.text: They may be promoting healthy behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: They may be contributing to unrealistic expectations about what pharmaceuticals can do.

options.label: D
options.text: They may not be effective in treating certain conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of a study looking back at 10 years of testosterone prescriptions?

options.label: A
options.text: Only half had been diagnosed with hypogonadism in the previous year.

options.label: B
options.text: All patients had been diagnosed with hypogonadism in the previous year.

options.label: C
options.text: The study found no correlation between testosterone prescriptions and hypogonadism.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential concern about the painkiller Vioxx?

options.label: A
options.text: It was more expensive than other painkillers.

options.label: B
options.text: It was not actually more effective than other painkillers.

options.label: C
options.text: It increased the risk of heart attacks and stroke.

options.label: D
options.text: It was only approved for certain conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of a Kaiser Permanente study on the impact of Vioxx and Celebrex on public health?

options.label: A
options.text: Ad exposure was linked to appropriate prescribing of Vioxx and Celebrex.

options.label: B
options.text: Ad exposure was linked to inappropriate prescribing of Vioxx and Celebrex.

options.label: C
options.text: The study found no correlation between ad exposure and prescribing.

multiple-choice.question: What is an argument in favor of prescription drug commercials?

options.label: A
options.text: They may be contributing to unrealistic expectations about what pharmaceuticals can do.

options.label: B
options.text: They may be promoting healthy behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: They may be contributing to the free flow of commercial information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the legal basis for prescription drug commercials in the US?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The government has not allowed prescription drug commercials.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescription drug commercials are only allowed for certain conditions.

title: Aphasia: The disorder that makes you lose your words - Susan Wortman-Jutt

multiple-choice.question: What is aphasia?

options.label: B
options.text: A disorder that affects only the hearing of a person.

options.label: C
options.text: A disorder that affects only the speaking of a person.

options.label: D
options.text: A disorder that affects only the reading of a person.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of aphasia that impairs expression.

options.label: C
options.text: A substitution of words or sounds that are used unintentionally.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of aphasia that affects only the hearing of a person.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for coordinating the muscles involved in speech.

options.label: D
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for movement.

multiple-choice.question: What is Wernicke's area?

options.label: A
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for naming objects.

options.label: B
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for comprehending language.

options.label: C
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for coordinating the muscles involved in speech.

options.label: D
options.text: A part of the brain responsible for movement.

multiple-choice.question: How many people in the U.S. have aphasia?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A rare form of aphasia caused by dementia.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of aphasia that affects only the hearing of a person.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of aphasia that affects only the speaking of a person.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal in treating PPA?

options.label: A
options.text: To improve language function for as long as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain language function for as long as possible before other symptoms of dementia occur.

multiple-choice.question: How can people with aphasia be helped?

options.label: A
options.text: By giving them extra time to speak.

options.label: B
options.text: By not giving them extra time to speak.

multiple-choice.question: What is brain plasticity?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's ability to improve itself.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's ability to get worse.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's ability to stay the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of FMRI studies in aphasia?

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how the brain works in people with aphasia.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is a vector? - David Huynh

multiple-choice.question: What is a scalar?

options.label: A
options.text: A quantity with magnitude and direction.

options.label: D
options.text: A quantity with no magnitude or direction.

multiple-choice.question: What makes vectors special and useful in various fields?

options.label: A
options.text: They change based on perspective and the coordinate system.

options.label: B
options.text: They remain invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used in video games and simulations.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in scientific simulations and car designs.

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean for a vector to be invariant to the coordinate system?

options.label: A
options.text: It means the vector changes based on the coordinate system.

options.label: B
options.text: It means the vector remains the same regardless of the coordinate system.

options.label: C
options.text: It means the vector is only used in one specific coordinate system.

options.label: D
options.text: It means the vector is only used in video games and simulations.

multiple-choice.question: What is a tensor?

options.label: B
options.text: A quantity with magnitude and direction.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of quantities with magnitude and direction that remain invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of quantities with no magnitude or direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a second-order tensor?

options.label: C
options.text: Stress, which is a combination of force and orientation.

options.label: D
options.text: A quantity with no magnitude or direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the array and the vector?

options.label: C
options.text: The array acquires meaning as a vector when assigned a coordinate basis.

options.label: D
options.text: The array and vector are completely unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the essence of what's being communicated by a vector?

options.label: C
options.text: The vector itself, regardless of the language used to describe it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between vectors and tensors?

options.label: A
options.text: Vectors are a type of tensor.

options.label: B
options.text: Tensors are a type of vector.

options.label: C
options.text: Vectors and tensors are both groups of quantities with magnitude and direction that remain invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: D
options.text: Vectors and tensors are completely unrelated.

title: Why some of us don't have one true calling - Emilie Wapnick

multiple-choice.question: At what age are children typically first asked the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"
According to the speaker, what is the problem with the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"

options.label: A
options.text: It's too easy and doesn't challenge children enough.

options.label: B
options.text: It inspires kids to dream about what they could be, but not about all that they could be.

options.label: C
options.text: It's only asked of kids and not of adults.

multiple-choice.question: What is a multipotentialite?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone with a single passion or interest.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone with many interests and creative pursuits.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is a specialist in one area.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is a generalist in many areas.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are three multipotentialite superpowers?

options.label: A
options.text: Idea synthesis, rapid learning, and time management.

options.label: B
options.text: Idea synthesis, rapid learning, and adaptability.

multiple-choice.question: What is idea synthesis, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Combining two or more fields to create something new.

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing on a single area of expertise.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing a new skill or talent.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is rapid learning?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to learn quickly and easily.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to apply knowledge from one area to another.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to focus on a single area of study.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to ignore new information and ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is adaptability, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to change one's mind or opinion.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to morph into whatever is needed in a given situation.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to ignore feedback and criticism.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to focus on a single goal or objective.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why is it important for multipotentialites to be themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are a minority and need to stick together.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a lot to offer and can solve complex problems.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are a threat to specialists and need to be suppressed.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are a waste of time and resources.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the ideal partnership between a specialist and a multipotentialite?

options.label: A
options.text: The specialist does all the work and the multipotentialite gets the credit.

options.label: B
options.text: The specialist and multipotentialite work together to create something new.

options.label: C
options.text: The specialist and multipotentialite work separately and don't interact.

options.label: D
options.text: The specialist and multipotentialite have a rivalry and compete with each other.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most important thing to take away from the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That multipotentialites are inferior to specialists.

options.label: B
options.text: That multipotentialites should try to be more like specialists.

options.label: C
options.text: That embracing one's inner wiring leads to a happier, more authentic life.

options.label: D
options.text: That multipotentialites should ignore their passions and interests.
